book.name: 1 Thessalonians
book.description: THE FIRST EPISTLE OF PAUL TO THE THESSALONIANS
book.info: Approximately A.D. 54, during Paul's second ministry journey, while he remained in Corinth ([link]1:1[/link]; [link]3:6[/link]; [link]Acts 18:1[/link], [link]5[/link]).
Corinth; see verses in the previous item.
book.subject: A Holy Life for the Church Life — Serving the Living God, Conducting Ourselves in a Holy Manner, and Waiting for the Lord's Coming

outlines.outline: The Content — A Holy Life for the Church
The Care of a Nursing Mother and an Exhorting Father
For the Living and Remaining Believers
The Day of the Lord Coming like a Thief
The Safeguard of Faith, Love, and Hope
The Believers' Cooperation — Living a Spiritual and Holy Life
God's Operation — Sanctifying and Preserving the Believers

verse.text: Paul and [xref]a[/xref]Silvanus and [xref]b[/xref]Timothy to the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]church of the [note]2[/note]Thessalonians in [note]3[/note]God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ: [xref]d[/xref]Grace to you and peace.
verse.note: This Epistle and 2 Thessalonians were addressed to the local church in Thessalonica, composed of all the believers in Christ in that city. Such a local church is of the believers and is in God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. This indicates that a local church is born of God the Father with His life and nature and is united with the Lord Jesus Christ organically in all that He is and has done. Hence, it is of men (such as the Thessalonians), yet is in God and in the Lord organically. This organic union in the divine life and nature is the vital base for the believers to live a holy life for the church life. Such a living is the theme of the two Epistles.

Thessalonica was a city of the Roman Empire, in the province of Macedonia, which was north of the province of Achaia. It was the next city the apostle Paul and his co-worker Silvanus visited after Philippi, after the Macedonian call he received on his second ministry journey ([link]Acts 16:9-12[/link]; [link]17:1-4[/link]). The apostle stayed and worked in Thessalonica for only a short time, probably less than one month ([link]Acts 17:2[/link]).

In this chapter the Triune God is revealed in His triune work upon us — the Father selected us ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]3-4[/link]), the Son delivers us ([link]v. 10[/link]), and the Holy Spirit propagates, imparts, and transmits the Triune God into us ([link]vv. 5-6[/link]). Such a triune work is for our enjoyment of His salvation.

verse.text: We [xref]a[/xref]thank God always concerning all of you, making [xref]b[/xref]mention [i]of you[/i] in our prayers,

Remembering unceasingly your [note]1[/note]work of [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith and [note]3[/note]labor of [xref]b[/xref]love and [note]4[/note]endurance of [xref]c[/xref]hope in our Lord Jesus Christ, before our God and Father;
verse.note: The Greek word denotes acts, actions, activities.

Here faith indicates the nature and strength of the work; love, the motivation for and characteristic of labor; and hope, the source of endurance. These depict the structure of the genuine Christian life, a life constructed with faith, love, and hope (see note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 13[/link]). Such a life originates not from the ability of the believers' natural being but from the infusion of what God, in whom they believe, is. It is carried out by their sacrificial love toward their loving Lord, who loved them and gave Himself for them, and toward His members, whom He has redeemed through His death in love. This life lasts and stands unchanging by the sustaining power of the hope in which the believers look for their beloved Lord, who promised that He would come to take them to Himself. Such a life is the content of this Epistle.[br][br]How marvelous that the Thessalonian believers could live such a life through the apostle's short ministry of less than one month! This encourages us to preach the complete gospel to typical unbelievers in full assurance of faith, and to minister the deeper truths concerning the Christian life to new converts.[br][br]In the two Epistles to the young church in Thessalonica, the genuine Christian life for the proper church life is revealed in a simple and brief way. It is a life of three dimensions in the light of the Lord's coming back, having faith as the beginning, the foundation, love as the process, the construction, and hope as the consummation, the completion. Faith is toward God ([link]v. 8[/link]), love is toward the saints ([link]3:12[/link]; [link]4:9-10[/link]), and hope is in the Lord's coming ([link]2:19[/link]). The first Epistle is for encouragement and comfort; the second is for correction and balance. The believers should live, walk, and work by faith and love in the hope of the Lord's coming back; but they should not have the erroneous concept that the Lord will come immediately and, thus, that they need not make any long-range plans. The apostle Paul's writings concerning the Christian life for the church life begin with the book of Romans and conclude with these two Epistles.
Or, toil, endeavoring, striving, working.
I.e., endurance issuing from hoping in our Lord Jesus Christ.

verse.text: Knowing, brothers, [xref]a[/xref]beloved of God, your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]selection;
verse.note: God's choosing before the foundation of the world for His eternal purpose ([link]Eph. 1:4[/link]). The apostles knew that the brothers, beloved of God, were chosen by God in such a manner for the fulfillment of His heart's desire.

verse.text: For our [xref]a[/xref]gospel did not come to you in word only, but also in [xref]b[/xref]power and in the [xref]c[/xref]Holy Spirit and in much assurance, even as you know [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]what kind of men we were among you for your sake.
verse.note: The apostles not only preached the gospel; they lived it. Their ministering of the gospel was not only by word but also by a life that displayed the power of God, a life in the Holy Spirit and in the assurance of their faith. They were the pattern of the glad tidings that they spread.

verse.text: And you became [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]imitators of us and of the Lord, having received the [note]2[/note]word in much affliction with [xref]b[/xref]joy of the [xref]c[/xref]Holy Spirit,
verse.note: Since the preachers were the pattern of the gospel, the believers became imitators of them. This, then, led the believers to follow the Lord, to take Him as their pattern ([link]Matt. 11:29[/link]).

The word preached by Paul was the embodiment of the Triune God, conveying and transmitting Him — the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit — into the believers in Christ. This word as the divine gospel was received by the Thessalonians, who were typical Gentile unbelievers.

verse.text: So that you became a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]pattern to all those who believe in [xref]b[/xref]Macedonia and in [xref]c[/xref]Achaia.
verse.note: The imitators of the apostles ([link]v. 6[/link]) became a pattern to all other believers.

verse.text: For from you the word of the Lord has sounded out; not only in Macedonia and in Achaia, but in every place, your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith toward God has gone out, so that we have no need of saying anything.
verse.note: This means that the believers' faith toward God sounded out together with the word of the Lord. Not only the Lord's objective word but also the believers' subjective faith went out.

verse.text: For they themselves report concerning us [note]1[/note]what kind of entrance we had toward you and how you [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]turned to God from the [xref]b[/xref]idols to [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]serve a [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]living and [xref]e[/xref]true God
verse.note: Implying a receptive welcome.

To turn to God from the idols, to serve a living and true God, and to await His Son from the heavens are the three basic substances of the Christian life as viewed from another angle. To turn to God from the idols is to turn away not only from the false gods, together with the devil and the demons behind them, but also from all things other than God. This is accomplished by faith infused into the new converts through their hearing of the word of the gospel. To serve a living and true God is to serve the very God who is triune — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — who has been processed to be the believers' life and life supply for their enjoyment. They should experience Him not only as the object of worship but also as the all-inclusive Supplier who lives in them. This experience is brought about by love produced within the believers by the sweet taste of the rich supply of the Father, through the Son, and in the Spirit. To await the Son of God from the heavens is to look for the One who passed through incarnation, human living, and crucifixion and entered into resurrection and ascended to the heavens, and who will come back to receive His believers into glory. This is the hope that strengthens the believers to stand steadfastly in their faith.
Lit., serve as a slave.

The living and true God is in contrast to the dead and false idols. God must be living and true to us and in us in our daily life, so that our present living will testify that the God whom we serve is living and true.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]await His Son from the [xref]b[/xref]heavens, whom He [xref]c[/xref]raised from the dead, Jesus, who [xref]d[/xref]delivers us from the [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]wrath which is coming.
verse.note: Because we are awaiting the Son of God from the heavens, our future is focused on Him. Our life declares that we have no hope on this earth and no positive destiny in this age, and that our hope is the coming Lord, who is our destiny forever. This governs, holds, and keeps our Christian life for the church life.
The wrath of the coming judgment of God ([link]Rom. 2:5-6[/link], [link]8-9[/link]).

verse.text: For you yourselves know, brothers, our [note]1[/note]entrance toward you, that it has not been [xref]a[/xref]in vain.
verse.note: The apostle stressed repeatedly their entrance toward the believers ([link]1:5[/link], [link]9[/link]). This shows that their manner of life played a great role in infusing the gospel into the new converts. It was not only what they said but what they were.

verse.text: But having suffered previously and having been outrageously treated, even as you know, in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Philippi, we were [xref]b[/xref]bold [note]2[/note]in our God to speak to you the gospel of God in much [xref]c[/xref]struggle.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Phil. 1[/link].
This was the apostles' experience of God in enjoying Him as their boldness in the struggle for the gospel.

verse.text: For our [xref]a[/xref]exhortation is not out of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]deception nor out of [xref]c[/xref]uncleanness nor in [xref]d[/xref]guile;
verse.note: [i]Deception[/i] refers to the goal, [i]uncleanness[/i] to the motive, and [i]guile[/i] to the means. All three are of and by the subtle and deceiving devil.

verse.text: But even as we have been [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]approved by God to be [xref]b[/xref]entrusted with the gospel, so we speak, not as [xref]c[/xref]pleasing men but God, who [xref]d[/xref]proves our hearts.
verse.note: God's entrusting depends on His approval, which comes out of His testing. The apostles were first tested and approved by God and then were entrusted by Him with the gospel. Hence, their speaking, the preaching of the gospel, was not of themselves to please men but of God to please Him. He proved, examined, and tested their hearts continually ([link]Psa. 26:2[/link]; [link]139:23-24[/link]).

verse.text: For neither were we found at any time with [xref]a[/xref]flattering speech, even as you know, nor with a [note]1[/note]pretext for [xref]b[/xref]covetousness; God is [xref]c[/xref]witness.
verse.note: Or, pretense, cloak. To have any pretext for covetousness is to peddle or adulterate the word of God ([link]2 Cor. 2:17[/link]; [link]4:2[/link]). It is also to pretend to be godly for the sake of gain ([link]1 Tim. 6:5[/link]; [link]Titus 1:11[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 2:3[/link]).

verse.text: Nor did we [note]1[/note]seek [xref]a[/xref]glory from men, neither from you nor from others, though we could have [note]2[/note]stood on our authority as [xref]b[/xref]apostles of Christ.
verse.note: To seek glory from men is a real temptation to every Christian worker. Many have been devoured and spoiled by this matter.

Or, asserted authority. Lit., been able to be in weight; i.e., been burdensome (cf. [link]v. 9[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 9:4-12[/link]). To assert authority, dignity, or right in Christian work damages that work. The Lord Jesus, while on earth, gave up His dignity ([link]John 13:4-5[/link]), and the apostle preferred not to use his right ([link]1 Cor. 9:12[/link]).

verse.text: But we were [xref]a[/xref]gentle in your midst, as a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]nursing mother would [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]cherish her own [xref]d[/xref]children.
verse.note: In some instances the Greek word means [i]a mother;[/i] hence, a nursing mother (cf. [link]Gal. 4:19[/link]).
Cherishing, which includes nourishing, indicates care that is more tender than mere nourishing. See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 5[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Yearning in this way over you, we were well pleased to impart to you not only the gospel of God but also [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]our own souls, because you became beloved to us.
verse.note: Being affectionately fond of, affectionately desirous of, like a nursing mother affectionately interested in her child, whom she nourishes and cherishes. This was what the apostles did with new believers. See note [link]17[sup]3[/sup][/link].

To live a clean and upright life, as portrayed in [link]vv. 3-6[/link] and [link]10[/link], and to love the new converts, even by giving our own souls to them, as described in [link]vv. 7-9[/link] and [link]11[/link], are the prerequisites for infusing them with the salvation conveyed in the gospel that we preach.

verse.text: For you remember, brothers, our labor and travail: While [xref]a[/xref]working night and day so as not to be [xref]b[/xref]burdensome to any of you, we proclaimed to you the gospel of God.
You are witnesses, as well as [xref]a[/xref]God, how in a [note]1[/note]holy and righteous and blameless manner we conducted ourselves toward you who believe,
verse.note: See note [link]75[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 1[/link]. [i]Holy[/i] refers to conduct toward God, [i]righteous[/i] to conduct toward men, and [i]blameless[/i] to conduct toward all — God, men, and Satan.

verse.text: Just as you know [note]1[/note]how [i]we were[/i] to each one of you, as a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]father to his own [xref]b[/xref]children, [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]exhorting you and consoling [i]you[/i] and testifying,
verse.note: The apostle was strong in stressing what or how they were ([link]1:5[/link]), because what they were opened the way to bring their new converts into God's full salvation.
In cherishing the believers as their own children, the apostles considered themselves a nursing mother; in exhorting the believers, a father.
Or, entreating.

verse.text: So that you might [xref]a[/xref]walk in a manner worthy of God, who [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]calls you into His own [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]kingdom and [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]glory.
verse.note: God's calling is according to His selection and follows His selection ([link]1:4[/link]).

As worshippers of idols ([link]1:9[/link]), the believers were in the kingdom of Satan ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link]). Now, through the salvation in Christ they were called, and they have believed into the kingdom of God, which is the sphere in which they can worship and enjoy God under the divine ruling with the view of entering into God's glory.
God's glory goes with His kingdom. See note [link]13[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 6[/link].

verse.text: And because of this we also [xref]a[/xref]thank God unceasingly that when you received [note]1[/note]the word of God, which you heard [note]2[/note]from us, you accepted [i]it[/i] not [i]as[/i] the word of men but even as it truly is, the word of God, which also [note]3[/note]operates in you who believe.
verse.note: Lit., the word of hearing of God from us.
The word received by the believers was from the apostles, but it was of God. Its source, its origin, was God and not the apostles.
Since the word of God is living and operative ([link]Heb. 4:12[/link]), it operates in the believing ones.

verse.text: For you, brothers, became [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]imitators of the [xref]b[/xref]churches of God which are in Judea in Christ Jesus, for you also suffered the same things from your own countrymen, even as they also from the Jews,
verse.note: The apostle taught the same thing in all the churches ([link]1 Cor. 4:17[/link]; [link]7:17[/link]; [link]11:16[/link]), indicating that all the churches should bear the same testimony of Jesus. Hence, the churches are all lampstands of the same kind ([link]Rev. 1:9[/link], [link]20[/link]).

verse.text: Who both [xref]a[/xref]killed the Lord Jesus and the [xref]b[/xref]prophets and [xref]c[/xref]drove us out; and they are not pleasing to God and are contrary to all men,
In that they forbid us to speak to the Gentiles that they may be saved, so that they [xref]a[/xref]fill up their sins always. But wrath has come upon them to the [note]1[/note]uttermost.
verse.note: Lit., to the end; hence, to the uttermost.

verse.text: But we, brothers, having been [note]1[/note]bereaved of you for [note]2[/note]a little while, in presence, [xref]a[/xref]not in heart, were more abundantly [note]3[/note]eager with great [xref]b[/xref]desire to see your face.
verse.note: This word implies that the apostles considered the new converts precious and dear to them. Paul likened their departure from them to a bereavement, a loss that they suffered through missing them.
Lit., the season of an hour.
This is the apostles' yearning over the new converts ([link]v. 8[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore we wanted to come to you, indeed I Paul, both once and again, yet [note]1[/note]Satan [xref]a[/xref]hindered us.
verse.note: Because the apostles were carrying out the will of God, Satan frustrated them.

verse.text: For what is our [xref]a[/xref]hope or [xref]b[/xref]joy or crown of [xref]c[/xref]boasting before our Lord Jesus at His [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]coming? Are not even you?
verse.note: Gk. [i]parousia,[/i] meaning [i]presence,[/i] as in [link]3:13[/link] and [link]4:15[/link]. The Lord's coming is His presence. In this light these two early Epistles were written. Every chapter of the first Epistle ends with the Lord's coming back.

verse.text: For you are our [note]1[/note]glory and joy.
verse.note: Since the apostles were the believers' nursing mother and exhorting father ([link]vv. 7[/link], [link]11[/link]), the believers, as the apostles' children, were their glory and joy.

verse.text: Therefore when we could [xref]a[/xref]bear [i]it[/i] no longer, we thought it good to be left in [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Athens alone,
verse.note: The chief city of the province of Achaia of the Roman Empire, where the apostle Paul preached the gospel to the philosophical Greeks ([link]Acts 17:15-34[/link]).

verse.text: And we sent [xref]a[/xref]Timothy, our brother and [note]1[/note]God's fellow worker in the gospel of Christ, to [xref]b[/xref]establish and [note]2[/note]encourage you for the sake of your [xref]c[/xref]faith,
verse.note: Some MSS read, minister of God. A minister of God is God's fellow worker ([link]1 Cor. 3:9[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:1[/link]). What a privilege! What a blessing!
Or, exhort, comfort.

verse.text: That no one would be [note]1[/note]shaken by these [xref]a[/xref]afflictions; for you yourselves know that we are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]appointed for this.
verse.note: If we are established in the faith ([link]v. 2[/link]), afflictions will work out for our good ([link]Rom. 8:28[/link]) according to God's purpose in His appointment. Otherwise, we may be shaken by the tempter ([link]v. 5[/link]) through the afflictions.

Or, destined, set, located. God has destined, appointed, that we should pass through afflictions. Hence, afflictions are God's allotted portion to us, and He has set us, located us, in a situation of afflictions.

verse.text: For even when we were with you, we [note]1[/note]told you beforehand that we are to be afflicted, even as it also came to pass and you know.
verse.note: Imperfect tense, indicating repeated action.

verse.text: Because of this, when I also could [xref]a[/xref]bear [i]it[/i] no longer, I sent to find out concerning your [xref]b[/xref]faith, lest perhaps the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]tempter had tempted you and our labor would be [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]in vain.
verse.note: The subtle devil, the old serpent, who tempted Eve ([link]Gen. 3:1-6[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 2:14[/link]).
The aim of the subtle tempter is to destroy the gospel work accomplished through God's fellow workers, so that it would be in vain.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]Timothy, having just come [note]1[/note]to us from you and announcing the good news to us of your [xref]b[/xref]faith and love and that you have kind [xref]c[/xref]remembrance of us always and [xref]d[/xref]long to see us, just as we also you,
verse.note: The apostle was in Corinth after leaving Athens ([link]Acts 17:15-16[/link]; [link]18:1[/link], [link]5[/link]). It was in Corinth that he wrote this lovely letter to the dear saints in Thessalonica for their encouragement.

verse.text: Because of this we were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]comforted because of you, brothers, in all our [note]2[/note]necessity and affliction, through your [xref]b[/xref]faith;
verse.note: The sound condition of the believers is always a comfort to God's fellow workers, who work on them and bear them as a burden.
Or, distress. See notes [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 7[/link] and [link]10[sup]3[/sup] in 2 Cor. 12[/link].

verse.text: Because now we [note]1[/note]live if you [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]stand firm in the Lord.
verse.note: The believers' standing firm in the Lord ministers life to the apostles.
Standing firm in the Lord is in contrast to being shaken from the faith ([link]v. 3[/link]).

verse.text: For what [xref]a[/xref]thanks can we return to God concerning you for all the joy with which we rejoice because of you before our God,
Night and day petitioning exceedingly so that we may [xref]a[/xref]see your face and [note]1[/note]complete the things that are lacking in your [xref]b[/xref]faith?
verse.note: Or, perfect. The verb form of the Greek word in [link]2 Cor. 13:9[/link] (see note 2 there). The believers in Thessalonica, being young in the Lord, were still lacking in their new faith. The apostle realized this with much loving concern for them. This was his reason for writing this Epistle.

verse.text: Now may our God and Father Himself and our Lord Jesus [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]make straight our path to you;
verse.note: In Greek, [i]make straight[/i] here is singular. This indicates that the apostle considered that God the Father and the Lord Jesus are one. How good to have our way in the ministry made straight by such a One! And how beautiful are the footsteps of the apostles in their carrying out of this One's ministry for the fulfilling of His purpose!

verse.text: And the Lord cause you to increase and [xref]a[/xref]abound in [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]love to [xref]c[/xref]one another and to all, just as we also to you,
verse.note: The apostle's concern for the young believers was first in regard to their faith ([link]vv. 2-10[/link]) and then in regard to their love, which issues from faith and works together with faith ([link]Gal. 5:6[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:14[/link] and note 2). Such love is an indication of growth in life ([link]1:3[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]So that He may [xref]a[/xref]establish your [note]2[/note]hearts [xref]b[/xref]blameless in [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]holiness before our God and Father at the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]coming of our Lord Jesus [xref]e[/xref]with all His [note]5[/note]saints. [note]6[/note]
verse.note: The establishing of the believers' hearts blameless issues from faith and love, as mentioned in the preceding verses. This spontaneously produces the hope of the coming back of our dear Lord, in whom we believe and whom we love. Hence, again we see that faith, love, and hope are the implied factors in the construction of this Epistle.

Inwardly, our heart must be established in holiness; outwardly, our body must be preserved in sanctification ([link]4:4[/link]; [link]5:23[/link]). This is so that we may have a holy life, and this holy life is for the church life.
See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link].
See note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

Believers in Christ (see notes [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link] and [link]2[sup]6[/sup] in 1 Cor. 1[/link]), including the Old Testament saints ([link]Dan. 7:18[/link], [link]21-22[/link], [link]25[/link], [link]27[/link]; [link]Zech. 14:5[/link]).
Some MSS add, Amen.

verse.text: Furthermore, brothers, we ask and [xref]a[/xref]exhort you in the Lord Jesus that even as you received from us how you ought to walk and [xref]b[/xref]please God, even as indeed you do walk, that you [xref]c[/xref]abound still more.
For you know what [xref]a[/xref]charges we gave you through the Lord Jesus.
For this is the [xref]a[/xref]will of God, your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sanctification: that you [xref]c[/xref]abstain from [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]fornication;
verse.note: See note [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 6[/link]. God's will is that His redeemed people, the believers in Christ, live a life of holiness according to His holy nature, a life wholly separated unto Him from anything other than Him. For this He is sanctifying us wholly ([link]5:23[/link]).

At Paul's time, in both Corinth and Thessalonica sensuality and immorality were rife in the pagan religions and even were fostered by pagan worship. Man was made to express God ([link]Gen. 1:26[/link]). Concerning this purpose, nothing ruins man more than fornication. This prevents man from being holy, separated unto God, and contaminates man to the uttermost in fulfilling God's holy purpose. Hence, the apostle strongly charged the newly converted Gentile believers to be sanctified unto God, to abstain from fornication, the most gross sin in the eyes of God, that they might avoid its damage and contamination.

verse.text: That each one of you know how to [note]1[/note]possess his [xref]a[/xref]own [note]2[/note]vessel in [note]3[/note]sanctification and [xref]b[/xref]honor,
verse.note: Implying to keep, to preserve.

Concerning the interpretation of [i]vessel[/i] here, there are two schools: one holds that the vessel is man's body, as in [link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]; the other, that it is a man's wife, as in [link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]. The context of this verse and the next verse, which include phrases such as [i]each one of you, in sanctification and honor,[/i] and especially [i]not in the passion of lust,[/i] justifies the interpretation of the first school but not that of the second. Here the apostle considered man's body his vessel, just as David did in [link]1 Sam. 21:5[/link]. In the same matter concerning the use of the body, both Paul and David considered man's body his vessel. To keep, or preserve, man's vessel in sanctification and honor, not allowing it to indulge in the passion of lust, is the safeguard against committing fornication.

Sanctification refers more to a holy condition before God; honor, to a respectable standing before man. Man was created for God's purpose with a high standing, and marriage was ordained by God for the propagation of man to fulfill God's purpose. Hence, marriage should be held in honor ([link]Heb. 13:4[/link]). To abstain from fornication is not only to remain in a sanctified condition before God but also to hold and keep a standing of honor before man.

verse.text: Not in the [xref]a[/xref]passion of lust, like the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles who do [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]not know God;
verse.note: That they do not know God is the basic reason that people indulge in the passion of lust.

verse.text: That no one [note]1[/note]overstep and [note]2[/note]take advantage of his brother in [note]3[/note]the matter, because the Lord is the [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]avenger concerning all [note]5[/note]these things, even as we also said before to you and solemnly charged.
verse.note: I.e., overpass (limits), overreach, transgress, go beyond. [i]Overstep and take advantage of his brother[/i] refers to the committing of adultery with a brother's wife.
Or, make a gain of; hence, defraud.
The matter of fornication, mentioned in [link]v. 3[/link].
The Lord judges fornicators and adulterers as an avenger, as a punisher, meting out justice.
Things such as overstepping and taking advantage of others.

verse.text: For God has not [xref]a[/xref]called us [note]1[/note]for [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]uncleanness but [note]3[/note]in [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]sanctification.
verse.note: Lit., based on.

The uncleanness of things such as fornication and adultery. Some teach that [i]uncleanness[/i] here refers to unfair gain in business, and that [link]v. 6[/link] speaks of taking advantage of a brother in doing business. However, such a teaching is not acceptable in light of the context of this section, which begins at [link]v. 3[/link] with the charge to abstain from fornication. Actually, [link]v. 7[/link] is the concluding word of this charge.
I.e., in the element of sanctification, in the sphere of God's holy nature.

The apostle's charge to abstain from fornication is based on sanctification ([link]v. 3[/link]), strengthened by sanctification ([link]v. 4[/link]), and concluded here with sanctification, because fornication, the most unclean thing, destroys the holy standing and character of God's called saints.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Consequently, he who [note]2[/note]rejects, rejects not man but God, who also gives His [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit to you.
verse.note: This verse is the conclusion of the section that begins with [link]v. 3[/link].
I.e., rejects the charge in the preceding verses.

The Holy Spirit given to us by God is the Holy One who sanctifies us, making us holy before God ([link]Rom. 15:16[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]). The will ([link]v. 3[/link]), the call ([link]v. 7[/link]), and the Spirit of God are all for our sanctification. First, God had His will, then He called us, and then He gave us His Holy Spirit. By His Spirit we can be sanctified to answer His call and fulfill His will.

verse.text: Now concerning [note]1[/note]brotherly [xref]a[/xref]love, you have no need [i]for me[/i] to [xref]b[/xref]write to you, for you yourselves are [xref]c[/xref]taught of God to [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]love one another;
verse.note: Gk. [i]philadelphia,[/i] composed of [i]phileo,[/i] to love (referring to love in general, as [i]to have affection for[/i]), and [i]adelphos,[/i] brother.
Gk. [i]agapao,[/i] referring to noble love.

verse.text: For you also do this unto all the brothers in the whole of [xref]a[/xref]Macedonia. But we [xref]b[/xref]exhort you, brothers, to [xref]c[/xref]abound still more
And to aspire to be [xref]a[/xref]quiet and attend to your own affairs and work with your [xref]b[/xref]hands, even as we [xref]c[/xref]charged you,
That you may walk [xref]a[/xref]becomingly toward those [xref]b[/xref]outside and may have [xref]c[/xref]need of nothing.
But we do not want you to be [xref]a[/xref]ignorant, brothers, concerning those who are [note]1[/note]sleeping, that you would not grieve even as also the rest who have [xref]b[/xref]no hope.
verse.note: I.e., dead ([link]v. 16[/link]; [link]John 11:11-14[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 11:30[/link]). For believers to die was considered by both the Lord and the apostle as going to sleep.

verse.text: For if we believe that Jesus died and [xref]a[/xref]rose, so also [xref]b[/xref]those who have fallen asleep through Jesus, God will bring [xref]c[/xref]with Him.

For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are living, who are left remaining unto the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]coming of the Lord, shall by no means precede those who have fallen asleep;
verse.note: Gk. [i]parousia,[/i] meaning [i]presence.[/i] See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link].

verse.text: Because the Lord Himself, with a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]shout of command, with the voice of the [xref]b[/xref]archangel and with the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]trumpet of God, will descend from [xref]d[/xref]heaven, and the [xref]e[/xref]dead in Christ will [xref]f[/xref]rise first.
verse.note: A signal for assembling.
The last trumpet ([link]1 Cor. 15:52[/link]), a trumpet for assembling God's redeemed people (cf. [link]Num. 10:2[/link]).

verse.text: Then we who are living, who are left remaining, will be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]caught up together [xref]b[/xref]with them in the [xref]c[/xref]clouds to meet the Lord [note]2[/note]in the air; and thus we will be always with the Lord.
verse.note: I.e., snatched up speedily and in a way that cannot be resisted. It is the same Greek word as in [link]Acts 8:39[/link] and [link]2 Cor. 12:2[/link], [link]4[/link]. The mentioning here of the rapture of the believers at the Lord's coming is in a general way, as a word of comfort. Details concerning this matter are revealed in other books of the New Testament, such as Matthew and Revelation.

In [link]Rev. 12[/link] the man-child, i.e., the overcomers, is caught up, raptured, to the throne of God in the third heaven before the great tribulation, the last three and a half years of the present age ([link]Rev. 12:5-6[/link], [link]14[/link]). Here, the majority of the believers, including those who are resurrected from the dead and those who are living at that time, are raptured to the air at the end of the great tribulation, at the time of the Lord's coming (parousia).

verse.text: Therefore comfort [xref]a[/xref]one another with these words.
But concerning the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]times and the seasons, brothers, you have no need [i]for anything[/i] to be [xref]b[/xref]written to you;
verse.note: These are the times and the seasons with regard to the Lord's coming. This is confirmed by [i]the day of the Lord[/i] in [link]v. 2[/link].

verse.text: For you yourselves know perfectly well that [note]1[/note]like a [xref]a[/xref]thief in the [xref]b[/xref]night, so the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]day of the Lord comes.
verse.note: This indicates that the day of the Lord's coming is kept secret and will come suddenly, being known beforehand by no one ([link]Matt. 24:42-43[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:3[/link]; [link]16:15[/link]).

In the preceding chapter the coming of the Lord is mainly for comfort and encouragement. In this chapter the day of the Lord is mainly for warning ([link]vv. 3-6[/link]), since it is mentioned in the Word mainly in relation to the Lord's judgment ([link]1 Cor. 1:8[/link]; [link]3:13[/link]; [link]5:5[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 1:14[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:8[/link]).

verse.text: When they say, [xref]a[/xref]Peace and security, then [note]1[/note]sudden [xref]b[/xref]destruction comes upon them, just as birth [xref]c[/xref]pangs to a woman with child; and they shall by no means escape.
verse.note: This is the result of men's intense rebellion against God under Satan's instigation near the time of the Lord's coming ([link]v. 2[/link]).

verse.text: But you, brothers, are not in [xref]a[/xref]darkness that the day should overtake you like a thief;
For you are all sons of [xref]a[/xref]light and sons of the [xref]b[/xref]day. We are not of the night nor of darkness.
So then let us not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sleep, as the rest do, but let us [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]watch and be [xref]c[/xref]sober.
verse.note: I.e., be unwatchful. So in the next verse.
[i]Watch[/i] is in contrast to [i]sleep[/i] in the next verse; [i]sober,[/i] in contrast to [i]drunk.[/i]

verse.text: For those who sleep, sleep during the [xref]a[/xref]night, and those who get [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]drunk are drunk during the night;
verse.note: In a stupor.

verse.text: But since we are of the [xref]a[/xref]day, let us be [xref]b[/xref]sober, putting on the [note]1[/note]breastplate of [xref]c[/xref]faith and love and a [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]helmet, the [note]2[/note]hope of [note]3[/note]salvation.
verse.note: The breastplate and the helmet here point to spiritual warfare. The breastplate, which covers and protects our heart and spirit according to God's righteousness ([link]Eph. 6:14[/link]), is of faith and love; the helmet, which covers and protects our mentality, our mind, is the hope of salvation ([link]Eph. 6:17[/link]). Faith, love, and hope are the three basic constructing elements of the genuine Christian life, as depicted in [link]1:3[/link]. Faith is related to our will, a part of our heart ([link]Rom. 10:9[/link]), and to our conscience, a part of our spirit ([link]1 Tim. 1:19[/link]); love is related to our emotion, another part of our heart ([link]Matt. 22:37[/link]); and hope is related to our understanding, the function of our mind. All these need to be protected so that a genuine Christian life can be maintained. Such a life is watchful and sober ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]). At the beginning of the Epistle, the apostle praised the believers' work of faith, labor of love, and endurance of hope ([link]1:3[/link]). Here, at the conclusion of the Epistle, he exhorted them to keep these spiritual virtues covered and protected by fighting for them.

The hope of our Lord's coming back ([link]1:3[/link]), which will be our salvation from both the coming destruction ([link]v. 3[/link]) and the slavery of corruption of the old creation ([link]Rom. 8:21-25[/link]).
Not salvation from eternal perdition through the Lord's death, but salvation from the coming destruction ([link]v. 3[/link]) through the Lord's coming back.

verse.text: For God did [note]1[/note]not [xref]a[/xref]appoint us to [xref]b[/xref]wrath but to the obtaining of [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ,
verse.note: Since God did not appoint us to wrath, we should watch, be sober, and fight ([link]vv. 6[/link], [link]8[/link]) to cooperate with God that we may obtain His salvation through the Lord Jesus.
See note [link]8[sup]3[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]died for us in order that whether we [note]2[/note]watch or [note]3[/note]sleep, we may [xref]b[/xref]live together [note]4[/note]with Him.
verse.note: The Lord died for us not only that we might be saved from eternal perdition but also that we may live together with Him through His resurrection. Such a living can save us from the coming destruction.
Or, are awake. I.e., are alive.
I.e., are dead ([link]4:13-15[/link]).
On the one hand, the Lord is away from us and we are awaiting His coming back; on the other hand, He is with us ([link]Matt. 28:20[/link]) and we can live together with Him ([link]Rom. 6:8[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore comfort [xref]a[/xref]one another, and [xref]b[/xref]build up each one the other, even as you also do.

Furthermore we ask you, brothers, to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]acknowledge [note]2[/note]those who labor among you and [note]3[/note]take the [xref]b[/xref]lead among you in the Lord and admonish you,
verse.note: Recognize and then render respect and regard for.
The apostle was probably referring here to the elders who labor in teaching and take the lead among the believers ([link]1 Tim. 5:17[/link]).

To take the lead is not mainly to rule but to set an example in doing things first, that others may follow. The elders not only should labor in teaching but also should do things as an example. The example may become a ground for their admonishing.

verse.text: And to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]regard them most highly in [xref]b[/xref]love because of their work. Be [note]2[/note]at [xref]c[/xref]peace among yourselves.
verse.note: "To lead the mind through a reasoning process to a conclusion" (Vincent); hence, to think of, to consider, to estimate, to esteem, to regard.
To regard the leading ones and to be at peace with one another is the proper condition of a local church.

verse.text: And we [xref]a[/xref]exhort you, brothers, Admonish the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]disorderly, console the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]fainthearted, sustain the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]weak, be [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]long-suffering toward all.
verse.note: Referring, perhaps, mainly to those who are idle and are unwilling to work, being busybodies ([link]2 Thes. 3:11[/link]), undisciplined, unruled, rebellious.
Lit., little-souled; i.e., narrow and feeble in the capacity of mind, will, and emotion.
Probably referring generally to the weak ones, who are weak either in their spirit or soul or body, or are weak in faith ([link]Rom. 14:1[/link]; [link]15:1[/link]).

This implies that in a local church, besides those who are disorderly and need admonishing, those who are little-souled and need consoling, and those who are weak and need sustaining, all the members may be a problem in some way and need us to be long-suffering toward them.

verse.text: See that no one repays anyone [xref]a[/xref]evil for evil, but [note]1[/note]always pursue what is [xref]b[/xref]good both for [xref]c[/xref]one another and for all.
verse.note: This means that regardless of how others treat us, even if their treatment is evil, we should pursue what is good for them.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Always [xref]a[/xref]rejoice,
verse.note: This is based on the conditions mentioned in [link]vv. 14-15[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Unceasingly [xref]a[/xref]pray,
verse.note: This is to have uninterrupted fellowship with God in our spirit. It requires perseverance ([link]Rom. 12:12[/link]; [link]Col. 4:2[/link]) with a strong spirit ([link]Eph. 6:18[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]In everything give [xref]a[/xref]thanks; [note]2[/note]for this is the [xref]b[/xref]will of God in Christ Jesus for you.
verse.note: Because all things work together for our good that we may be transformed and conformed to the image of Christ ([link]Rom. 8:28-29[/link]).
This clause modifies the three preceding exhortations. God wants us to live a rejoicing, praying, and thanking life. Such a life is a glory to God and a shame to His enemy.

verse.text: Do [note]1[/note]not quench the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit;
verse.note: The Spirit causes our spirit to be burning ([link]Rom. 12:11[/link]) and our gifts to be flaming ([link]2 Tim. 1:6[/link]). Hence, we should not quench Him.

verse.text: Do not [note]1[/note]despise [note]2[/note]prophecies,
verse.note: Count as nothing, lightly esteem.
I.e., prophesying, the prophetic speech that issues from a revelation. It does not need to be a prediction (see [link]1 Cor. 14:1[/link], [link]3-4[/link] and notes there).

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]prove all things. Hold fast to what is [xref]a[/xref]good;
verse.note: Including to discern prophecies ([link]1 Cor. 14:29[/link]), to discern the spirits ([link]1 Cor. 12:10[/link]), to test the spirits ([link]1 John 4:1[/link]), to prove what is the will of God ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]), and to prove what is well pleasing to the Lord ([link]Eph. 5:10[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Abstain from every [note]1[/note]kind of evil.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]species.[/i] It denotes anything in view, anything in perception; hence, a sight. It refers not to the appearance of evil but to the kind, the form, the shape, the sight, of evil. The believers, who live a holy life in faith, love, and hope, should abstain from evil of any kind.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the [note]2[/note]God of [xref]a[/xref]peace Himself [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]sanctify you [note]4[/note]wholly, and may your [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]spirit and [xref]d[/xref]soul and [xref]e[/xref]body be [xref]f[/xref]preserved [note]6[/note]complete, [xref]g[/xref]without blame, [note]7[/note]at the [note]8[/note][xref]h[/xref]coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: [i]And[/i] conjoins the blessing of God's sanctifying of our entire being, given in this verse, and the charge to abstain from every kind of evil, given in the preceding verse. On the one hand, we abstain from every kind of evil; on the other hand, God sanctifies us wholly. We cooperate with God that we may have a holy living.
The God of peace is the Sanctifier; His sanctification brings in peace. When we are wholly sanctified by Him from within, we have peace with Him and with man in every way ([link]v. 13[/link]).
To set apart, separate unto God, from things common or profane. See notes [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link] and [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 6[/link].
Or, entirely, thoroughly, to the consummation. God sanctifies us wholly, so that no part of our being, of either our spirit or soul or body, will be left common or profane.

This word strongly indicates that man is of three parts: spirit, soul, and body. The spirit as our inmost part is the inner organ, possessing God-consciousness, that we may contact God ([link]John 4:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:9[/link]). The soul is our very self (cf. [link]Matt. 16:26[/link]; [link]Luke 9:25[/link]), a medium between our spirit and our body, possessing self-consciousness, that we may have our personality. The body as our external part is the outer organ, possessing world-consciousness, that we may contact the material world. The body contains the soul, and the soul is the vessel that contains the spirit. In the spirit, God as the Spirit dwells; in the soul, our self dwells; and in the body, the physical senses dwell. God sanctifies us, first, by taking possession of our spirit through regeneration ([link]John 3:5-6[/link]); second, by spreading Himself as the life-giving Spirit from our spirit into our soul to saturate and transform our soul ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]); and last, by enlivening our mortal body through our soul ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link], [link]13[/link]) and transfiguring our body by His life power ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]). See notes [link book="Heb." chapter="4"]12[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link].

God not only sanctifies us wholly but also preserves our spirit, soul, and body complete. [i]Wholly[/i] is quantitative; [i]complete[/i] is qualitative. Quantitatively, God sanctifies us wholly; qualitatively, God preserves us complete, i.e., He keeps our spirit, soul, and body perfect. Through the fall our body was ruined, our soul was contaminated, and our spirit was deadened. In God's full salvation our entire being is saved and made complete and perfect. For this, God is preserving our spirit from any deadening element ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link]), our soul from remaining natural and old ([link]Matt. 16:24-26[/link]), and our body from the ruin of sin ([link]4:4[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:6[/link]). Such a preservation by God and His thorough sanctification sustain us to live a holy life unto maturity that we may meet the Lord in His parousia.
Or, in the presence (parousia).

Every chapter of this book ends with the coming of the Lord. This shows that the writer, Paul, lived and worked with the Lord's coming before him, taking it as an attraction, an incentive, a goal, and a warning. He not only did this himself but also encouraged the believers under his care to do the same.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Faithful is He who [xref]b[/xref]calls you, who [note]1[/note]also will [xref]c[/xref]do [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The faithful God who called us will also sanctify us wholly and preserve our entire being complete.

verse.text: Brothers, [xref]a[/xref]pray also for us.
Greet all the brothers with a holy [xref]a[/xref]kiss.
I adjure you by the Lord to have this letter [xref]a[/xref]read to all the [note]1[/note]brothers.
verse.note: Some MSS insert, [i]holy.[/i] This would mean that, since this Epistle is concerned with the holy life of the believers, the apostle in his concluding charge called the believers "the holy brothers."

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.
verse.note: See notes [link book="John" chapter="1"]14[sup]6[/sup][/link] and [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in John 1[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]. It is only when we enjoy the Lord as grace that we can live a holy life for the church life, a life that is genuine and proper for the church, lived by our having the Lord as the life supply.[br][br]In this book the holy life for the church life is developed. To be sanctified is to be holy. In the universe, only God is holy; only He is distinct and different from all other things. He is not common and therefore is undefiled. Holiness is God's nature; it is an intrinsic characteristic of God's attributes. Therefore, to be holy completely and entirely, to be holy not only in outward position but also in inward disposition, we must have the holy nature that is characteristic of God. To have this divine nature of God, we must possess God, having Him as our life and nature. Only God can sanctify us wholly and can preserve our entire being, our spirit and soul and body, complete, keeping it from being common or defiled. God desires to sanctify us, and He Himself will do it, as long as we are willing to pursue Him as holiness ([link]Heb. 12:14a[/link]) and cooperate with Him in this matter. In this way we can be holy as He is holy ([link]1 Pet. 1:15-16[/link]). Without holiness we cannot see Him ([link]Heb. 12:14b[/link]).[br][br]God not only has made us holy in position by the redeeming blood of Christ ([link]Heb. 13:12[/link]; [link]10:29[/link]) but also is sanctifying us in disposition by His own holy nature. By thus sanctifying us, He transforms us in the essence of our spirit, soul, and body, making us wholly like Him in nature. In this way He preserves our spirit, soul, and body wholly complete. His making us holy in position is outside of us, whereas His sanctifying us in disposition is within us, beginning from our spirit, the deepest part, passing through our soul, the intermediate part, and reaching to our body, the outer part. This work, which penetrates us deeply, is accomplished through the regeneration of our spirit ([link]John 3:6[/link]), the transformation of our soul ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]), and the redemption of our body ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:30[/link]) by God's life-giving Spirit. Such a holy and sanctified life is necessary for us to have a church life that is pleasing to God and that expresses Him.
